Deep in the jungle, where the mighty tiger lies
 Bill and his elephants were taken by surprise

In 1968 Richard Cooke the third an American Photographer for national geographic visiting India at the same time as the Beatles at the maharishi meditation camp went hunting for tigers. He rode on the back of an elephant because it was deemed to be the safest way to hunt dangerous animals at the time. Allegedly he was riding in the Rishikesh Indian bush and his elephant was startled by a tiger which Richard subsequently killed.
 Tiger hunting was then and is today the subject of great controversy. John Lennon expressed his mixed feeling about it in an interview where he pointed out the hypocrisy of a man killing a tiger in between meditation sessions

“If looks could kill, it would have been us instead of him”

According to the Free Dictionary –

a catchphrase said when someone makes a frown at someone or when someone casts a dirty look.



For sure a threat for which someone (the tiger) must be shot.
So Captain Marvel zapped him right between the eyes

John is mocking Americans' infatuation with comic books heroes.



In the comics, Captain Marvel is actually a young boy named Billy Batson who, upon shouting the magic words, “Shazam!”, transforms into a grown man with incredible superpowers.

John is commenting on the fact that, despite being comparable to a child in his immaturity, Cooke sees himself as some macho hero after he kills the poor animal.

In light of John Lennon’s antipathy towards McCartney’s Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da, it may seem odd that he was responsible for this overly frivolous singalong that appeared on the White Album.

The song was written in Rishikesh, India. It was inspired by an American visitor who departed for a tiger-killing spree before returning to the ashram to seek spiritual enlightenment.

That was written about a guy in Maharishi’s meditation camp who took a short break to go shoot a few poor tigers, and then came back to commune with God. There used to be a character called Jungle Jim and I combined him with Buffalo Bill. It’s a sort of teenage social-comment song and a bit of a joke. Yoko’s on that one, I believe, singing along.
-John Lennon

The American in question was Richard Cooke III, known as Rik, whose mother Nancy was also on the meditation course in Rishikesh.

Then a self-important, middle-aged American woman arrived, moving a mountain of luggage into the brand-new private bungalow next to Maharishi’s along with her son, a bland young man named Bill. People fled this newcomer, and no one was sorry when she left the ashram after a short time to go tiger hunting, unaware that their presence had inspired a new Beatles song – Bungalow Bill.
-Mia Farrow

Both Rik and Nancy went on the tiger shoot. Upon their return Rik told the Maharishi of his feelings of remorse, in a meeting at which Lennon and McCartney were both present.

Rik told me that he felt bad about it and said that he didn’t think he’d ever kill an animal again. Maharishi said, ‘You had the desire Rik and now you don’t have the desire?’ Then John asked, ‘Don’t you call that slightly life destructive?’ I said, ‘Well John, it was either the tiger or us. The tiger was right where we were’. That came up in the lyric as ‘If looks could kill it would have been us instead of him’.
-Nancy Cooke

The children asked him if to kill was not a sin
 “Not when he looked so fierce,” his mummy butted in

Lennon mocks his trigger-happy attitude. No one questioned whether or not the act he committed was sin. His macho, heroic act seemed to redeem the terrible crime to nature that he so effortlessly endured. It also goes back to the comic portrayal of his overbearing mother, attempting to justify the killing.

This is also the first time a woman or non-Beatle performed lead vocals in a Beatles track, in this case it being Yoko Ono, Lennon’s muse and later wife.
He’s the all American, bullet-headed, Saxon mother’s son

Evidently, Cooke and his mother got along well with all of the Beatles aside from Lennon. Lennon, in turn, looked down on Cooke, especially when he shot a tiger on impulse. Lennon was inspired to write a song that mocked Cooke’s bravado.
In case of accidents, he always took his mum

Richard A. Cooke III, the inspiration for Bungalow Bill, was visiting his mother, Nancy Cooke de Herrera, at the Ashram of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi at the same time as the Beatles. Both she and her son maintained friendly relations with The Beatles for the duration of their stay, exception John Lennon, the sole author of this song, who by Cooke de Herrera’s account was “a genius” but distant and contemptuous. Lennon is obviously making a jab at Cooke’s masculinity by portraying him as dependent on his mother for emotional support.
